        <gmd:MD_DataIdentification id="DataIdentification">
            <gmd:citation>
                <gmd:CI_Citation>
                    <gmd:title>

                    </gmd:title>
                    <gmd:date>
                        <gmd:CI_Date>

                            <gmd:dateType>

                        <gmd:CI_Date>

                        </gmd:CI_Date>
                    </gmd:date>
                    <gmd:identifier>
                        <gmd:MD_Identifier>
                            <gmd:authority>
                                <gmd:CI_Citation>
                                    <gmd:title>
                                        <gco:CharacterString>Willowbrook Watershed Services. 2022-04-30. "WQ Response to Geologic Variation" (dataset). 2.0.0. DataStream. https://doi.org/10.25976/fbxm-3b32.</gco:CharacterString>
                                    </gmd:title>

                                </gmd:CI_Citation>
                            </gmd:authority>

                            </gmd:code>
                        </gmd:MD_Identifier>
                    </gmd:identifier>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                            <gmd:organisationName>
                                <gco:CharacterString>Willowbrook Watershed Services</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="author">author
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                            <gmd:organisationName>
                                <gco:CharacterString>Willowbrook Watershed Services</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="contributor">contributor
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                </gmd:CI_Citation>
            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>With altered precipitation regimes and variable groundwater resources being major factors affecting water quality, we initiated a project which incorporated bedrock and surficial geology as well as stream discharge to explain variability in water samples within local areas. If you were to look at the geology maps within the Oromocto River watershed you would see vast differences between the South Branch and the North Branch of the Oromocto River combined with the Rusagonis Stream. The South Branch runs through a variety of rock formations from the Ordovician, Silurian, Devonian, and up to Late Carboniferous periods while the North Branch Oromocto and tributaries run almost exclusively through Late Carboniferous bedrock which extends in a northerly direction all the way to the St. John River. With differing abilities to buffer acidity and differing chemistry for redox reactions, exploring how the water quality in the two principal branches reacts to groundwater resources was done by sampling two or more streams of each surficial and bedrock geology type. By exploring the range of water quality within the two sub catchments and comparing and contrasting these variables with land use, discharge and seasonal fluctuations, it is possible to observe trends in the data both temporally and spatially.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>
            <gmd:credit gco:nilReason="missing"/>

            <gmd:status>
                <gmd:MD_ProgressCode

                codeListValue="onGoing">onGoing</gmd:MD_ProgressCode>
            </gmd:status>

                    </gmd:keyword>

            </gmd:descriptiveKeywords>

            </gmd:resourceConstraints>

            </gmd:language> 
            
            
            <gmd:topicCategory>
                <gmd:MD_TopicCategoryCode>inlandWaters</gmd:MD_TopicCategoryCode>
            </gmd:topicCategory>

                    <gmd:geographicElement>
                        <gmd:EX_GeographicBoundingBox>
                            <gmd:extentTypeCode>
                                <gco:Boolean>1</gco:Boolean>
                            </gmd:extentTypeCode>
                            <gmd:westBoundLongitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>-66.861817</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:westBoundLongitude>
                            <gmd:eastBoundLongitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>-66.42615</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:eastBoundLongitude>
                            <gmd:southBoundLatitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>45.45745</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:southBoundLatitude>
                            <gmd:northBoundLatitude>
                                <gco:Decimal>47.7853</gco:Decimal>
                            </gmd:northBoundLatitude>
                        </gmd:EX_GeographicBoundingBox>
                    </gmd:geographicElement>
                    <gmd:temporalElement>
                        <gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>
                            <gmd:extent>
                                <gml:TimePeriod gml:id="TimePeriod">
                                    <gml:description>seconds</gml:description>
                                    <gml:beginPosition>2018-06-11T00:00:00+00:00</gml:beginPosition>
                                    <gml:endPosition>2018-09-06T00:00:00+00:00</gml:endPosition>
                                </gml:TimePeriod>
                            </gmd:extent>
                        </gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>
                    </gmd:temporalElement>
                    <gmd:verticalElement>
                        <gmd:EX_VerticalExtent>
                        <gmd:minimumValue gco:nilReason="missing" />
                        <gmd:maximumValue gco:nilReason="missing" />

                        </gmd:EX_VerticalExtent>
                    </gmd:verticalElement>
                </gmd:EX_Extent>

    </gmd:identificationInfo>

keywords_translation_method.fr: Keyword text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

name: 10-25976-fbxm-3b32
notes: With altered precipitation regimes and variable groundwater resources being major factors affecting water quality, we initiated a project which incorporated bedrock and surficial geology as well as stream discharge to explain variability in water samples within local areas. If you were to look at the geology maps within the Oromocto River watershed you would see vast differences between the South Branch and the North Branch of the Oromocto River combined with the Rusagonis Stream. The South Branch runs through a variety of rock formations from the Ordovician, Silurian, Devonian, and up to Late Carboniferous periods while the North Branch Oromocto and tributaries run almost exclusively through Late Carboniferous bedrock which extends in a northerly direction all the way to the St. John River. With differing abilities to buffer acidity and differing chemistry for redox reactions, exploring how the water quality in the two principal branches reacts to groundwater resources was done by sampling two or more streams of each surficial and bedrock geology type. By exploring the range of water quality within the two sub catchments and comparing and contrasting these variables with land use, discharge and seasonal fluctuations, it is possible to observe trends in the data both temporally and spatially.

notes_translated.en: With altered precipitation regimes and variable groundwater resources being major factors affecting water quality, we initiated a project which incorporated bedrock and surficial geology as well as stream discharge to explain variability in water samples within local areas. If you were to look at the geology maps within the Oromocto River watershed you would see vast differences between the South Branch and the North Branch of the Oromocto River combined with the Rusagonis Stream. The South Branch runs through a variety of rock formations from the Ordovician, Silurian, Devonian, and up to Late Carboniferous periods while the North Branch Oromocto and tributaries run almost exclusively through Late Carboniferous bedrock which extends in a northerly direction all the way to the St. John River. With differing abilities to buffer acidity and differing chemistry for redox reactions, exploring how the water quality in the two principal branches reacts to groundwater resources was done by sampling two or more streams of each surficial and bedrock geology type. By exploring the range of water quality within the two sub catchments and comparing and contrasting these variables with land use, discharge and seasonal fluctuations, it is possible to observe trends in the data both temporally and spatially.
notes_translated.fr: La modification des régimes de précipitations et la variabilité des ressources en eaux souterraines étant des facteurs majeurs influant sur la qualité de l'eau, nous avons lancé un projet intégrant la géologie du substrat rocheux et de la surface ainsi que le débit des cours d'eau pour expliquer la variabilité des échantillons d'eau dans les zones locales. Si vous examiniez les cartes géologiques du bassin versant de la rivière Oromocto, vous constateriez de grandes différences entre les branches sud et nord de la rivière Oromocto combinées au ruisseau Rusagonis. La branche sud traverse diverses formations rocheuses datant de l'Ordovicien, du Silurien, du Dévonien et jusqu'au Carbonifère supérieur, tandis que la branche nord d'Oromocto et ses affluents traversent presque exclusivement le substrat rocheux du Carbonifère supérieur qui s'étend vers le nord jusqu'au fleuve Saint-Jean. Compte tenu de leurs capacités différentes à atténuer l'acidité et de leur composition chimique différente pour les réactions redox, nous avons étudié la façon dont la qualité de l'eau des deux branches principales réagit aux ressources en eaux souterraines en échantillonnant au moins deux cours d'eau de chaque type de surface et de géologie du substrat rocheux. En explorant la gamme de qualité de l'eau dans les deux sous-bassins versants et en comparant et en contrastant ces variables avec l'utilisation des terres, le débit et les fluctuations saisonnières, il est possible d'observer les tendances des données à la fois temporellement et spatialement.

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.

title: WQ Response to Geologic Variation

title_translated.fr: Réponse du QW aux variations géologiques
